name: Salzburg
fun_fact: Fun fact: Salzburg means 'Salt Fortress' - the city's wealth came from salt mines in the nearby mountains, and you can still visit the 7,000-year-old Hallstatt salt mine, the oldest in the world.

hero_dishes.name: Wiener Schnitzel
hero_dishes.description: Veal cutlet pounded thin, breaded, and fried to golden perfection, served with potato salad and lemon
hero_dishes.origin_story: While Vienna gets the name, Salzburg serves some of Austria's best schnitzel. The dish must be made with veal (legally protected) - pork is a different dish entirely. The cutlet should be so thin it's almost transparent, with a crispy coating that puffs away from the meat.

The fluffy egg-white peaks are dusted with powdered sugar like snow-capped Alps. It's always one size (supposedly for two, but easily feeds nine!) and must be eaten immediately before it deflates.

hero_dishes.name: Backhendl
hero_dishes.description: Crispy fried chicken, Austria's answer to American fried chicken but with European finesse
hero_dishes.origin_story: B√§renwirt has served backhendl since 1663, perfecting the technique over 360 years. The chicken is considered the best in Austria - crispy coating, juicy meat. The cozy tavern atmosphere (like a hunting lodge) adds to the experience.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: B√§renwirt (traditional Austrian inn dedicated to preserving iconic culture since 1663 - renowned for best fried chicken in Austria)

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Austrian Tafelspitz
hero_dishes.description: Boiled beef served in broth with root vegetables, horseradish, and apple-horseradish sauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Emperor Franz Joseph's favorite dish became Austrian culinary heritage. The beef (from the hip) is boiled gently until tender, then served with its broth. It's comfort food that requires skill - proper timing makes perfect tenderness.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gasthaus Pichler (best Tafelspitz in Graz), Landhauskeller, traditional gasth√§user

signature_drinks.name: Stiegl Beer
signature_drinks.description: Salzburg's local brewery founded in 1492, Austria's largest private brewery
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in traditional beer steins at beer gardens and taverns. Augustiner Br√§ust√ºbl is Austria's biggest beer tavern (monastery brewery) where monks have brewed since 1621. Locals fill their own steins from wooden barrels - it's theatrical and traditional.

signature_drinks.name: Austrian Wine
signature_drinks.description: Crisp Gr√ºner Veltliner whites and elegant reds from nearby wine regions
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: While Salzburg doesn't grow wine (too mountainous), wine from Wachau and other Austrian regions flows freely. Locals appreciate quality Austrian wines with dinner, pairing thoughtfully with schnitzel and other dishes.
